CCLoader's guide to modloader installation: https://github.com/CCDirectLink/CCLoader/wiki/Installing-CCLoader

error.description: A command that errors if run in a non-NSFW channel. Does nothing else.

embed.title: Format Syntax
embed.description:
The formatter has a few rules.
`%/%/` outside of any invocation are repeated verbatim and will ignore `%` and `%/` until the next space. This is for URL compatibility.
`%%` will cause the next character to ignore these rules, except `(` outside of an invocation. This rule overrides any later rule, and can override the previous rule if the start gets escaped.
`%%(` will begin an invocation, space separates arguments within an invocation, `)` ends it, and invocations can nest with further `()` - without the `%%`.
`/ABC/` is equivalent to `%%(emote ABC)` outside of lists and anything between `%/%/` and a space, for the sake of URLs.
Prefixing a value with `'` wraps it as so: `(%%' value)`
It is important to note that it *does* work to put invocations in a list, as so: `%%((thing1) (thing2))`; the result of the last invocation will be returned.
This can be used to silence invocations.
Finally, double-quotes (") around some text escapes everything except other double-quotes.

For further details, please see the other commands in the -formatter group.

embed.title: Invocation execution and recursion
embed.description:
Invocations generally evaluate their parameters as invocations. (There are some exceptions.)
An invocation that is a string is returned as-is, but lists are evaluated.
Invocations may thus be nested, such as `(name (cause))`.
In the case of random-element, for example, you may not want this; see the ' invocation for a way around this.

embed.title: Types
embed.description:
The formatter has two types, strings and lists.
Numbers are strings that are then strictly checked to be safe integers with no additional padding.
The 'number?' invocation checks to see if a value is a valid number.

help-booleans.description: About booleans and the not invocation

embed.title: Booleans
embed.description:
False is an empty string. Anything else is true.
However, if true needs to be returned by a library function, it will be returned as 'true'.
The not invocation is equivalent to `(if A "" "true")` where A is the parameter; that is, it returns the boolean opposite of the input.

embed.title: The ' invocation
embed.description:
The ' invocation uses a special prefix syntax, where `'1` is equivalent to `(%%' 1)`. It has a single parameter.
The parameter is returned as-is - *without evaluation*.
Example: `%%(random-element '(1 2 3))` -> `1` or `2` or `3`

embed.title: The 'list' invocation
embed.description: The 'list' invocation has an arbitrary amount of parameters. It returns a list containing them all in order after evaluation.

embed.title: The 'length' invocation
embed.description: The 'length' invocation takes a single parameter and returns its length.

embed.title: The 'nth' invocation
embed.description:
The 'nth' invocation takes two parameters: an index and a list.
It returns a value from the given index of the list; these indexes begin at 0.
Example: `%%(nth 0 '(3 2 1))` -> `3`

embed.title: The comparison invocations
embed.description:
<=, >=, <, > take two parameters, which are numbers, perform a comparison, and return the result.
== and != work on strings, too.

embed.title: The maths invocations
embed.description:
+ and \* take an arbitrary amount of numeric parameters, and add/multiply them together respectively.
Given no input, + will return 0 and \* will return 1.
- meanwhile requires 2 numeric parameters, subtracting the second from the first and returning the result.

embed.title: The 'random-element' invocation
embed.description:
The 'random-element' invocation takes a single parameter, which is a list of possible outputs.
It returns one, unless this doesn't make sense, in which case it will return whatever it likes.
Example: See the ' invocation.

embed.title: The 'random' invocation
embed.description:
The 'random' invocation takes a single parameter, which is the number of possible results, and returns a number from 0 to that number - 1.
If the input is less than 0, expect shenanigans.

embed.title: The 'strcat' invocation
embed.description: The 'strcat' invocation concatenates all the parameters given, which must be strings, returning the result.

embed.title: The 'if' invocation
embed.description:
The 'if' invocation takes two to three parameters.
It will only run & return the result of the second if the first is true, and will run & return the result of the third (if present) otherwise.

embed.title: The 'set' invocation
embed.description:
The 'set' invocation takes two parameters: a string for an invocation name, and some arbitrary value.
It creates a new invocation type at the relevant scope that simply returns the given value.

embed.title: The 'set-func' invocation
embed.description:
The 'set-func' invocation never ever evaluates its parameters.
The first parameter can be a string or a list.
If it's a string, the second parameter must also be a string, and set-func copies the function referred to by the second parameter to the first.
If the first parameter is not a string, it must be a list of the form (name arg1 arg2 arg3) or such.
There may be as many or as few arguments as you want, but the name must always be present and a string.
The second parameter is code to run in the function that will be created with the given name and parameters.
The parameters are evaluated and copied to local variables in a new scope (inside the scope where set-func was run) before your code is run.
Combined with the `bootstrap` user setting, this allows you to create simple macros.

embed.title: The 'emote' invocation
embed.description:
The 'emote' invocation has a single parameter: The reference used to get the emote.
This can be at least an emote ID, emote name, or the actual emote in written form.
It is subject to per-guild overrides.
Example: `%%(emote leaCheese)` -> `%(emote leaCheese)`

embed.title: The 'quote', 'quote-cause', 'quote-silent', 'quote-silent-cause' invocations
embed.description:
The 'quote' invocation receives a Discord message URL (or simply a channel ID followed by a message ID, separated by %/), and regurgitates it as a quotation.
This will fail if the Writer (for guild settings, this means 'the guild') doesn't have access.
Example: `%%(quote https://discordapp.com/channels/143364538958348288/367424200991965184/604035298686402770)`
Additional note: 'quote-cause' is this but has stricter permissions checks, so the Cause must *also* have access.
Additional additional note: 'quote-silent' avoids pinging the original message author.
Additional additional additional note: 'quote-silent-cause' combines these.

embed.title: The 'prefix' invocation
embed.description: The 'prefix' invocation returns the relevant bot prefix.

embed.title: The 'cause' invocation
embed.description: The 'cause' invocation returns the user ID of the user who 'caused' the execution to take place.

embed.title: The 'name' invocation
embed.description:
The 'name' invocation takes a single parameter, the user ID to name.
It returns the local name of that user.
For safety reasons, the user must be a member of the relevant guild, or this will simply return their ID as-is.

embed.title: The 'find-user' invocation
embed.description:
The 'find-user' invocation takes a single parameter, a string representing that user.
It will return the user ID as a string, or false otherwise.

embed.title: The 'args' invocation
embed.description: The 'args' invocation has no parameters, and returns the list of command arguments if relevant.

embed.title: The 'embed' invocation
embed.description:
The 'embed' invocation has one parameter: the embed description.
Descriptions of valid embed descriptions will be shown via examples.
Deleting an existing embed: `%%(embed "")`
Example Image (note the ' - the embed details may come from other invocations):
`%%(embed '(image "CrossCode Stream Drawing; see https://discordapp.com/channels/143364538958348288/461638004490895390/602281244977528832" "https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/uUAgjHNYZu7IWdIaV_WtDafdo6vqpJsam63_XxvN4d3107yMlESv2XTHQuWFoENLUCFQuCtmNLbq_A=w1366-h679"))`
